Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; worn white slip; interior: glazed streaky black with two added white bands; exterior: painted decoration consisting of lower part of figure, possibly Peleus, hastening to right; wearing short chiton with dotted lower hem and possible dotted belt at waist (with hind leg of a spotted animal or animal skin on left); oddly formed right leg in faint outline; four-leafed rosettes as filling ornament; below, billet band between brown lines above trace of undetermined motif.
Curator's comments: According to Price, the figure may be Peleus. Because the tail and the paw of the animal skin seem to belong to a living animal, perhaps this is Thetis. The registration number A768.2 is from Smith's unpublished catalogue.

Lemos describes the sherd as belonging to the Group with the Filling Ornament. The features typical for this group of vessels are the milky white slip and the use of filling ornament, which is found only in this group of sherds. The presence of filling ornament also suggests that the vases were mostly likely the earliest in the Grand Style. The male figures portrayed on vases from this group are perhaps the most expertly depicted and may all have been done by the same hand. The depiction of male figures in this group is done in outline as the male figure appears here. In later Grand Style vases, male figures are depicted with coloured flesh. Finally, the attempt at creating some perspective is rather clumsy.
